End.description: The cross-start margin edges of the flex items are placed flush with the cross-end edge of the line.

Baseline.description: If the flex item's inline axes are the same as the cross axis, this value is identical to "Start". Otherwise, it participates in baseline alignment: all participating box items on the line are aligned such that their baselines align, and the item with the largest distance between its baseline and its cross-start margin edge is placed flush against the cross-start edge of the line.
Baseline.helpDescription: If the flex item's inline axes are the same as the cross axis, this value is identical to "Start". Otherwise, it participates in baseline alignment: all participating box items on the line are aligned such that their baselines align, and the item with the largest distance between its baseline and its cross-start margin edge is placed flush against the cross-start edge of the line.

Bottom.helpDescription: Popover will be placed at the bottom of the reference control.

PreferredTopOrFlip.description: Popover will be placed to the top of the reference control. If the available space is less than the Popover's height, it will appear to the bottom of the same reference control top border.
PreferredTopOrFlip.helpDescription: Popover will be placed to the top of the reference control. If the available space is less than the Popover's height, it will appear to the bottom of the same reference control top border.

Both.description: Both directions (left to right or right to left)
Both.helpDescription: Both directions (left to right or right to left)

Auto.description: Takes up the value of alignItems from the parent FlexBox
Auto.helpDescription: Takes up the value of alignItems from the parent FlexBox

Center.description: The flex item's margin box is centered in the cross axis within the line.
Center.helpDescription: The flex item's margin box is centered in the cross axis within the line.

Start.description: The cross-start margin edges of the flex item is placed flush with the cross-start edge of the line.
Start.helpDescription: The cross-start margin edges of the flex item is placed flush with the cross-start edge of the line.

Stretch.description: Make the cross size of the item's margin box as close to the same size as the line as possible.
Stretch.helpDescription: Make the cross size of the item's margin box as close to the same size as the line as possible.

End.description: The cross-start margin edges of the flex item is placed flush with the cross-end edge of the line.
End.helpDescription: The cross-start margin edges of the flex item is placed flush with the cross-end edge of the line.

Baseline.description: If the flex item's inline axis is the same as the cross axis, this value is identical to "Start". Otherwise, it participates in baseline alignment: all participating box items on the line are aligned such that their baselines align, and the item with the largest distance between its baseline and its cross-start margin edge is placed flush against the cross-start edge of the line.
Baseline.helpDescription: If the flex item's inline axis is the same as the cross axis, this value is identical to "Start". Otherwise, it participates in baseline alignment: all participating box items on the line are aligned such that their baselines align, and the item with the largest distance between its baseline and its cross-start margin edge is placed flush against the cross-start edge of the line.

Inherit.description: Inherits the value from its parent.
Inherit.helpDescription: Inherits the value from its parent.

Delete.description: Delete mode (only one list item can be deleted via provided delete button)
Delete.helpDescription: Delete mode (only one list item can be deleted via provided delete button)

MultiSelect.description: Multi selection mode (more than one list item can be selected).
MultiSelect.helpDescription: Multi selection mode (more than one list item can be selected).

SingleSelect.description: Right-positioned single selection mode (only one list item can be selected).
SingleSelect.helpDescription: Right-positioned single selection mode (only one list item can be selected).

SingleSelectMaster.description: Selected item is highlighted but no selection control is visible (only one list item can be selected).
SingleSelectMaster.helpDescription: Selected item is highlighted but no selection control is visible (only one list item can be selected).

SingleSelectLeft.description: Left-positioned single selection mode (only one list item can be selected).
SingleSelectLeft.helpDescription: Left-positioned single selection mode (only one list item can be selected).

Down.description: The actual value is less than the target value.
Down.helpDescription: The actual value is less than the target value.

Up.description: The actual value is more than the target value.
Up.helpDescription: The actual value is more than the target value.

KeyValue.description: A key-value pair formatted like "(key) text"
KeyValue.helpDescription: A key-value pair formatted like "(key) text"

Navigation.description: This default mode is suitable if the number of items is unlimited or if there is no editable field within the item. While the last/first interactive element within an item has the focus, pressing tab/shift+tab moves the focus to the next/previous element in the tab chain after/before the sap.m.List or sap.m.Table.

sap.m.Switch.description: A switch is a user interface control on mobile devices that is used for change between binary states. The user can also drag the button handle or tap to change the state.
sap.m.Switch.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new Switch. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getState state} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getCustomTextOn customTextOn} : string (default: )
    • {@link #getCustomTextOff customTextOff} : string (default: )
    • {@link #getEnabled enabled} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getName name} : string (default: )
    • {@link #getType type} : sap.m.SwitchType (default: Default)
  • Associations
    • {@link #getAriaLabelledBy ariaLabelledBy} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Control)[]
  • Events
    • {@link #event:change change} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.m.Switch.helpDescription: A switch is a user interface control on mobile devices that is used for change between binary states. The user can also drag the button handle or tap to change the state.

The placeholder will be hidden and have zero dimensions (display: none). See {@link sap.ui.core.RenderManager#writeInvisiblePlaceholderData RenderManager#writeInvisiblePlaceholderData} for details.

busyIndicatorSize.description: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. If the size could vary in width and the width could get smaller than 3rem, the sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Auto option could be used. The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.
busyIndicatorSize.helpDescription: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. sap.m.MessagePopoverItem.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new MessagePopoverItem. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

    • {@link #getLongtextUrl longtextUrl} : sap.ui.core.URI

sap.m.semantic.SemanticPage.description:
A semantic page is an enhanced {@link sap.m.Page}, that can contain controls with semantic meaning @see sap.m.semantic.SemanticControl.
Content specified in the {@link sap.m.semantic.SemanticPage#semanticControls} aggregations will be automatically positioned in dedicated sections of the footer or the header of the page, depending on the control's semantics.
For example, a semantic button of type {@link sap.m.semantic.PositiveAction} will be positioned in the right side of the footer, and in logically correct sequence order with respect to any other included semantic controls.
The full list of what we internally define for semantic content is:
  • Visual properties (e.g. AddAction will be styled as an icon button)
  • Position in the page (UX guidelines specify that some buttons should be in the header only, while others are in the footer or the "share" menu, so we do the correct positioning)
  • Sequence order (UX guidelines define a specific sequence order of semantic controls with respect to each other)
  • Default localized tooltip for icon-only buttons
  • Overflow behavior (UX quidelines define which buttons are allowed to go to the overflow of the toolbar when the screen gets narrower). For icon buttons, we ensure that the text label of the button appears when the button is in overflow, as specified by UX.
  • Screen reader support (invisible text for reading the semantic type)
In addition to the predefined semantic controls, the SemanticPage can host also custom application-provided controls. It preserves most of the API of {@link sap.m.Page} for specifying page content.
sap.m.semantic.SemanticPage.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new SemanticPage Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getTitle title} : string
    • {@link #getTitleLevel titleLevel} : sap.ui.core.TitleLevel (default: Auto)
    • {@link #getShowNavButton showNavButton} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getShowSubHeader showSubHeader} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getEnableScrolling enableScrolling} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getShowFooter showFooter} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getFloatingFooter floatingFooter} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getSemanticRuleSet semanticRuleSet} : sap.m.semantic.SemanticRuleSetType (default: Classic)
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getSubHeader subHeader} : sap.m.IBar
    • {@link #getContent content} : sap.ui.core.Control[] (default)
    • {@link #getCustomHeaderContent customHeaderContent} : sap.m.Button[]
    • {@link #getCustomFooterContent customFooterContent} : sap.m.Button[]
    • {@link #getLandmarkInfo landmarkInfo} : sap.m.PageAccessibleLandmarkInfo
  • Events
    • {@link #event:navButtonPress navButtonPress} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.m.semantic.SemanticPage.helpDescription:
A semantic page is an enhanced {@link sap.m.Page}, that can contain controls with semantic meaning @see sap.m.semantic.SemanticControl.
Content specified in the {@link sap.m.semantic.SemanticPage#semanticControls} aggregations will be automatically positioned in dedicated sections of the footer or the header of the page, depending on the control's semantics.
For example, a semantic button of type {@link sap.m.semantic.PositiveAction} will be positioned in the right side of the footer, and in logically correct sequence order with respect to any other included semantic controls.
The full list of what we internally define for semantic content is:
  • Visual properties (e.g. AddAction will be styled as an icon button)
  • Position in the page (UX guidelines specify that some buttons should be in the header only, while others are in the footer or the "share" menu, so we do the correct positioning)
  • Sequence order (UX guidelines define a specific sequence order of semantic controls with respect to each other)
  • Default localized tooltip for icon-only buttons
  • Overflow behavior (UX quidelines define which buttons are allowed to go to the overflow of the toolbar when the screen gets narrower). For icon buttons, we ensure that the text label of the button appears when the button is in overflow, as specified by UX.
  • Screen reader support (invisible text for reading the semantic type)
In addition to the predefined semantic controls, the SemanticPage can host also custom application-provided controls. It preserves most of the API of {@link sap.m.Page} for specifying page content.

sap.m.PullToRefresh.description: PullToRefresh control. Put it as the first control in contents of a scroll container or a scrollable page. Do not place it into a page with disabled scrolling. On touch devices it gets hidden by default and when the user pulls down the page far enough, it gets visible and triggers the "refresh" event. In non-touch browsers where scrollbars are used for scrolling, it is always visible and triggers the "refresh" event when clicked.
sap.m.PullToRefresh.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new PullToRefresh. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getDescription description} : string
    • {@link #getShowIcon showIcon} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getCustomIcon customIcon} : sap.ui.core.URI
    • {@link #getIconDensityAware iconDensityAware} : boolean (default: true)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:refresh refresh} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.m.PullToRefresh.helpDescription: PullToRefresh control. Put it as the first control in contents of a scroll container or a scrollable page. Do not place it into a page with disabled scrolling. On touch devices it gets hidden by default and when the user pulls down the page far enough, it gets visible and triggers the "refresh" event. In non-touch browsers where scrollbars are used for scrolling, it is always visible and triggers the "refresh" event when clicked.

selectedButton.description: A reference to the currently selected button control. By default or if the association is set to false (null, undefined, "", false), the first button will be selected. If the association is set to an invalid value (for example, an ID of a button that does not exist) the selection on the SegmentedButton will be removed.

sap.m.SegmentedButton.description: SegmentedButton is a horizontal control made of multiple buttons, which can display a title or an image. It automatically resizes the buttons to fit proportionally within the control. When no width is set, the control uses the available width.
sap.m.SegmentedButton.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new SegmentedButton. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getWidth width} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize
    • {@link #getEnabled enabled} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getSelectedKey selectedKey} : string (default: )
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getButtons buttons} : sap.m.Button[] (default)
    • {@link #getItems items} : sap.m.SegmentedButtonItem[]
  • Associations
    • {@link #getSelectedButton selectedButton} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.m.Button)
    • {@link #getAriaDescribedBy ariaDescribedBy} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Control)[]
    • {@link #getAriaLabelledBy ariaLabelledBy} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Control)[]
  • Events
    • {@link #event:select select} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.m.SegmentedButton.helpDescription: SegmentedButton is a horizontal control made of multiple buttons, which can display a title or an image. It automatically resizes the buttons to fit proportionally within the control. When no width is set, the control uses the available width.

buttons.description:
Deprecated! Since 1.28.0 Instead use the "items" aggregation.
The buttons of the SegmentedButton control. The items set in this aggregation are used as an interface for the buttons displayed by the control. Only the properties ID, icon, text, enabled and textDirections of the Button control are evaluated. Setting other properties of the button will have no effect. Alternatively, you can use the createButton method to add buttons.
buttons.helpDescription:
Deprecated! Since 1.28.0 Instead use the "items" aggregation.
The buttons of the SegmentedButton control. The items set in this aggregation are used as an interface for the buttons displayed by the control. Only the properties ID, icon, text, enabled and textDirections of the Button control are evaluated. Setting other properties of the button will have no effect. Alternatively, you can use the createButton method to add buttons.

selectedKey.description: Key of the selected item. If no item to this key is found in the items aggregation, no changes will apply. Only the items aggregation is affected. If duplicate keys exist, the first item matching the key is used.

busyIndicatorSize.description: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. If the size could vary in width and the width could get smaller than 3rem, the sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Auto option could be used. The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.

sap.m.UploadCollection.description:
This control allows you to upload single or multiple files from your devices (desktop, tablet or phone) and attach them to the application.

The consuming application needs to take into account that the consistency checks of the model during the upload of the file need to be performed, for example, if the user is editing or deleting a file.
sap.m.UploadCollection.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new UploadCollection. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getFileType fileType} : string[]
    • {@link #getMaximumFilenameLength maximumFilenameLength} : int
    • {@link #getMaximumFileSize maximumFileSize} : float
    • {@link #getMimeType mimeType} : string[]
    • {@link #getMultiple multiple} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getNoDataText noDataText} : string
    • {@link #getSameFilenameAllowed sameFilenameAllowed} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getShowSeparators showSeparators} : sap.m.ListSeparators (default: All)
    • {@link #getUploadEnabled uploadEnabled} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getUploadUrl uploadUrl} : string (default: ../../../upload)
    • {@link #getInstantUpload instantUpload} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getNumberOfAttachmentsText numberOfAttachmentsText} : string
    • {@link #getMode mode} : sap.m.ListMode (default: None)
    • {@link #getUploadButtonInvisible uploadButtonInvisible} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getTerminationEnabled terminationEnabled} : boolean (default: true)
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getItems items} : sap.m.UploadCollectionItem[] (default)
    • {@link #getHeaderParameters headerParameters} : sap.m.UploadCollectionParameter[]
    • {@link #getParameters parameters} : sap.m.UploadCollectionParameter[]
    • {@link #getToolbar toolbar} : sap.m.OverflowToolbar
    • {@link #getInfoToolbar infoToolbar} : sap.m.Toolbar
  • Events
    • {@link #event:change change} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:fileDeleted fileDeleted} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:filenameLengthExceed filenameLengthExceed} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:fileRenamed fileRenamed} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:fileSizeExceed fileSizeExceed} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:typeMissmatch typeMissmatch} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:uploadComplete uploadComplete} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:uploadTerminated uploadTerminated} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:beforeUploadStarts beforeUploadStarts} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:selectionChange selectionChange} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.m.UploadCollection.helpDescription:
This control allows you to upload single or multiple files from your devices (desktop, tablet or phone) and attach them to the application.

The consuming application needs to take into account that the consistency checks of the model during the upload of the file need to be performed, for example, if the user is editing or deleting a file.

multiple.description: Lets the user select multiple files from the same folder and then upload them. Internet Explorer 8 and 9 do not support this property. multiple.helpDescription: Lets the user select multiple files from the same folder and then upload them. Internet Explorer 8 and 9 do not support this property. mode.description: Defines the selection mode of the control (e.g. None, SingleSelect, MultiSelect, SingleSelectLeft, SingleSelectMaster). sap.m.DateRangeSelection.description:
Overview

The {@link sap.m.DateRangeSelection} is a single-field input control that enables the users to enter a localized date range using touch, mouse, keyboard input, or by selecting a date range in the calendar. They can also navigate directly from one month or year to another.

Note: The {@link sap.ui.unified.Calendar} is used internally only if the DateRangeSelection is opened (not used for the initial rendering). If the sap.ui.unified library is not loaded before the DateRangeSelection is opened, it will be loaded upon opening. This could lead to a waiting time when the DateRangeSelection is opened for the first time. To prevent this, apps using the DateRangeSelection should also load the sap.ui.unified library.

Usage

When to use
If you need a time range and know that your user is a power user who has to input lots of data. If the keyboard is the primary device used for navigating the app, use two input fields. This allows the user to quickly jump from field to field. By selecting a date in one of the fields, the other field should recognize the information and jump to the same selection.

When not to use
If the user's primary goal is not to select ranges or if you just want to enter a date and a time. For such cases, use the {@link sap.m.DatePicker} or {@link sap.m.TimePicker}.

The user can enter a date by:
  • Using the calendar that opens in a popup
  • Typing it in directly in the input field (not available for mobile devices)
On app level, there are two options to provide a date for the DateRangeSelection - date range as a string to the value property or JavaScript Date objects to the dateValue and secondDateValue properties (only one of these options should be used at a time):
  • Use the value property if the date range is already provided as a formatted string
  • Use the dateValue and secondDateValue properties if the date range is already provided as JavaScript Date objects or you want to work with JavaScript Date objects
Formatting

All formatting and parsing of dates from and to strings is done using the {@link sap.ui.core.format.DateFormat}. If a date is entered by typing it into the input field, it must fit to the used date format and locale.

Supported format options are pattern-based on Unicode LDML Date Format notation. See {@link http://unicode.org/reports/tr35/#Date_Field_Symbol_Table}

For example, if the displayFormat is "MMM d, y", delimiter is "-", and the used locale is English, a valid value string is "Jul 29, 2015 - Jul 31, 2015" and it is displayed in the same way in the input field.

If no placeholder is set to the DateRangeSelection, the used displayFormat is displayed as a placeholder. If another placeholder is needed, it must be set.

Note: If the string does NOT match the displayFormat (from user input) or the valueFormat (on app level), the {@link sap.ui.core.format.DateFormat} makes an attempt to parse it based on the locale settings. For more information, see the respective documentation in the API Reference.

Responsive behavior

The DateRangeSelection is fully responsive. It is smaller in compact mode and provides a touch-friendly size in cozy mode.
sap.m.DateRangeSelection.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new DateRangeSelection. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getDelimiter delimiter} : string (default: -)
    • {@link #getSecondDateValue secondDateValue} : object
    • {@link #getFrom from} : object
    • {@link #getTo to} : object
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.m.DatePicker#constructor sap.m.DatePicker} can be used as well.

valueFormat.description: The date string expected and returned in the value property uses this format. By default the short format of the used locale is used. Supported format options are pattern-based on Unicode LDML Date Format notation. {@link http://unicode.org/reports/tr35/#Date_Field_Symbol_Table} For example, if the date string represents an ABAP DATS type, the format should be "yyyyMMdd". Note: If data binding on value property with type sap.ui.model.type.Date is used, this property will be ignored. The format defined in the binding will be used.
valueFormat.helpDescription: The date string expected and returned in the value property uses this format. By default the short format of the used locale is used. Supported format options are pattern-based on Unicode LDML Date Format notation. {@link http://unicode.org/reports/tr35/#Date_Field_Symbol_Table} For example, if the date string represents an ABAP DATS type, the format should be "yyyyMMdd". Note: If data binding on value property with type sap.ui.model.type.Date is used, this property will be ignored. The format defined in the binding will be used.

displayFormat.description: The date is displayed in the input field using this format. By default, the medium format of the used locale is used. Supported format options are pattern-based on Unicode LDML Date Format notation. {@link http://unicode.org/reports/tr35/#Date_Field_Symbol_Table} Note: If you use data binding on the value property with type sap.ui.model.type.Date this property will be ignored. The format defined in the binding will be used.
displayFormat.helpDescription: The date is displayed in the input field using this format. By default, the medium format of the used locale is used. Supported format options are pattern-based on Unicode LDML Date Format notation. {@link http://unicode.org/reports/tr35/#Date_Field_Symbol_Table} Note: If you use data binding on the value property with type sap.ui.model.type.Date this property will be ignored. The format defined in the binding will be used.

sap.m.semantic.SemanticSelect.description: A semantic select is a {@link sap.m.Select} eligible for aggregation content of a {@link sap.m.semantic.SemanticPage}.
sap.m.semantic.SemanticSelect.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new SemanticSelect. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getEnabled enabled} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getSelectedKey selectedKey} : string (default: )
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getItems items} : sap.ui.core.Item[] (default)
  • Associations
    • {@link #getSelectedItem selectedItem} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Item)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:change change} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.m.semantic.SemanticControl#constructor sap.m.semantic.SemanticControl} can be used as well.
sap.m.semantic.SemanticSelect.helpDescription: A semantic select is a {@link sap.m.Select} eligible for aggregation content of a {@link sap.m.semantic.SemanticPage}.

sap.m.BusyIndicator.description: Control to indicate that the system is busy with some task and the user has to wait.
sap.m.BusyIndicator.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new BusyIndicator. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getText text} : string (default: )
    • {@link #getTextDirection textDirection} : sap.ui.core.TextDirection (default: Inherit)
    • {@link #getCustomIcon customIcon} : sap.ui.core.URI (default: )
    • {@link #getCustomIconRotationSpeed customIconRotationSpeed} : int (default: 1000)
    • {@link #getCustomIconDensityAware customIconDensityAware} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getCustomIconWidth customIconWidth} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: 44px)
    • {@link #getCustomIconHeight customIconHeight} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: 44px)
    • {@link #getSize size} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: 1rem)
    • {@link #getDesign design} : string (default: auto)
  • Associations
    • {@link #getAriaLabelledBy ariaLabelledBy} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Control)[]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.m.BusyIndicator.helpDescription: Control to indicate that the system is busy with some task and the user has to wait.

busyIndicatorSize.description: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. If the size could vary in width and the width could get smaller than 3rem, the sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Auto option could be used. The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.

The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.

customIconDensityAware.description: If this is set to false, the src image will be loaded directly without attempting to fetch the density perfect image for high density device. By default, this is set to true but then one or more requests are sent to the server, trying to get the density perfect version of the specified image. If bandwidth is the key for the application, set this value to false.

If bandwidth is the key for the application, set this value to false.

sap.m.P13nConditionPanel.description: The ConditionPanel Control will be used to implement the Sorting, Filtering and Grouping panel of the new Personalization dialog.
sap.m.P13nConditionPanel.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new P13nConditionPanel. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getMaxConditions maxConditions} : string (default: -1)
    • {@link #getExclude exclude} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getContainerQuery containerQuery} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getAutoAddNewRow autoAddNewRow} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getDisableFirstRemoveIcon disableFirstRemoveIcon} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getAlwaysShowAddIcon alwaysShowAddIcon} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getUsePrevConditionSetting usePrevConditionSetting} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getAutoReduceKeyFieldItems autoReduceKeyFieldItems} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getLayoutMode layoutMode} : string
    • {@link #getShowLabel showLabel} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getDisplayFormat displayFormat} : string
    • {@link #getValidationExecutor validationExecutor} : object
  • Aggregations
  • Events
    • {@link #event:dataChange dataChange} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.

sap.m.IconTabBar.description:
The IconTabBar control represents a collection of tabs with associated content.

IconTabBar covers the following use cases: - Filter – There is only one main content for all tabs. The main content can be filtered, based on the selected tab. - Normal tab bar - The contents of each tab are independent from each other. - Combination of the above - There can be both filtered and independent contents.
sap.m.IconTabBar.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new IconTabBar. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getShowSelection showSelection} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getExpandable expandable} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getExpanded expanded} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getSelectedKey selectedKey} : string
    • {@link #getUpperCase upperCase} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getStretchContentHeight stretchContentHeight} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getApplyContentPadding applyContentPadding} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getBackgroundDesign backgroundDesign} : sap.m.BackgroundDesign (default: Solid)
    • {@link #getHeaderMode headerMode} : sap.m.IconTabHeaderMode (default: Standard)
    • {@link #getShowOverflowSelectList showOverflowSelectList} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getHeaderBackgroundDesign headerBackgroundDesign} : sap.m.BackgroundDesign (default: Solid)
    • {@link #getEnableTabReordering enableTabReordering} : boolean (default: false)
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getItems items} : sap.m.IconTab[]
    • {@link #getContent content} : sap.ui.core.Control[]
  • Events
    • {@link #event:select select} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:expand expand} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.m.IconTabBar.helpDescription:
The IconTabBar control represents a collection of tabs with associated content.

IconTabBar covers the following use cases: - Filter – There is only one main content for all tabs. The main content can be filtered, based on the selected tab. - Normal tab bar - The contents of each tab are independent from each other. - Combination of the above - There can be both filtered and independent contents.

busyIndicatorSize.description: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. If the size could vary in width and the width could get smaller than 3rem, the sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Auto option could be used. The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.

sap.m.Wizard.description: The Wizard control enables users to accomplish a single goal which consists of multiple dependable sub-tasks. Each sub-task is provided in the form of a WizardStep.
sap.m.Wizard.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new Wizard. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getWidth width} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: auto)
    • {@link #getHeight height} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: 100%)
    • {@link #getShowNextButton showNextButton} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getFinishButtonText finishButtonText} : string (default: Review)
    • {@link #getEnableBranching enableBranching} : boolean (default: false)
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getSteps steps} : sap.m.WizardStep[] (default)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:stepActivate stepActivate} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:complete complete} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.

enableBranching.description: Enables the branching functionality of the Wizard. Branching gives the developer the ability to define multiple routes a user is able to take based on the input in the current step. It is up to the developer to programatically check for what is the input in the current step and set a concrete next step amongs the available subsequent steps. Note: If this property is set to false, next and subSequentSteps associations of the WizardStep control are ignored.

sap.m.ListBase.description: The sap.m.ListBase control provides a base functionality of the sap.m.List and sap.m.Table controls. Selection, deletion, unread states and inset style are also maintained in sap.m.ListBase. Note: The ListBase including all contained items may be completely re-rendered when the data of a bound model is changed. Due to the limited hardware resources of mobile devices this can lead to longer delays for lists that contain many items. As such the usage of a list is not recommended for these use cases.
sap.m.ListBase.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new ListBase. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getInset inset} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getHeaderText headerText} : string
    • {@link #getHeaderDesign headerDesign} : sap.m.ListHeaderDesign (default: Standard)
    • {@link #getFooterText footerText} : string
    • {@link #getMode mode} : sap.m.ListMode (default: None)
    • {@link #getWidth width} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: 100%)
    • {@link #getIncludeItemInSelection includeItemInSelection} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getShowUnread showUnread} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getNoDataText noDataText} : string
    • {@link #getShowNoData showNoData} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getEnableBusyIndicator enableBusyIndicator} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getModeAnimationOn modeAnimationOn} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getShowSeparators showSeparators} : sap.m.ListSeparators (default: All)
    • {@link #getSwipeDirection swipeDirection} : sap.m.SwipeDirection (default: Both)
    • {@link #getGrowing growing} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getGrowingThreshold growingThreshold} : int (default: 20)
    • {@link #getGrowingTriggerText growingTriggerText} : string
    • {@link #getGrowingScrollToLoad growingScrollToLoad} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getGrowingDirection growingDirection} : sap.m.ListGrowingDirection (default: Downwards)
    • {@link #getRememberSelections rememberSelections} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getKeyboardMode keyboardMode} : sap.m.ListKeyboardMode (default: Navigation)
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getItems items} : sap.m.ListItemBase[] (default)
    • {@link #getSwipeContent swipeContent} : sap.ui.core.Control
    • {@link #getHeaderToolbar headerToolbar} : sap.m.Toolbar
    • {@link #getInfoToolbar infoToolbar} : sap.m.Toolbar
  • Associations
    • {@link #getAriaLabelledBy ariaLabelledBy} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Control)[]
  • Events
    • {@link #event:select select} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:selectionChange selectionChange} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:delete delete} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:swipe swipe} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:growingStarted growingStarted} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:growingFinished growingFinished} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:updateStarted updateStarted} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:updateFinished updateFinished} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:itemPress itemPress} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.m.ListBase.helpDescription: The sap.m.ListBase control provides a base functionality of the sap.m.List and sap.m.Table controls. Selection, deletion, unread states and inset style are also maintained in sap.m.ListBase. Note: The ListBase including all contained items may be completely re-rendered when the data of a bound model is changed. Due to the limited hardware resources of mobile devices this can lead to longer delays for lists that contain many items. As such the usage of a list is not recommended for these use cases.

rememberSelections.description: If set to true, this control remembers and retains the selection of the items after a binding update has been performed (e.g. sorting, filtering). Note: This feature works only if two-way data binding for the selected property of the item is not used. It also needs to be turned off if the binding context of the item does not always point to the same entry in the model, for example, if the order of the data in the JSONModel is changed.

showNoData.description: Defines whether or not the text specified in the noDataText property is displayed.
showNoData.helpDescription: Defines whether or not the text specified in the noDataText property is displayed.

models.description: A map of model instances to which the object should be attached. The models are keyed by their model name. For the default model, String(undefined) is expected.

visible.description: Whether the control should be visible on the screen. If set to false, a placeholder will be rendered to mark the location of the invisible control in the DOM of the current page. The placeholder will be hidden and have zero dimensions (display: none). See {@link sap.ui.core.RenderManager#writeInvisiblePlaceholderData RenderManager#writeInvisiblePlaceholderData} for details.
visible.helpDescription: Whether the control should be visible on the screen. If set to false, a placeholder will be rendered to mark the location of the invisible control in the DOM of the current page. The placeholder will be hidden and have zero dimensions (display: none). See {@link sap.ui.core.RenderManager#writeInvisiblePlaceholderData RenderManager#writeInvisiblePlaceholderData} for details.

swipeDirection.description: Defines the direction of the swipe movement (e.g LeftToRight, RightToLeft, Both) to display the control defined in the swipeContent aggregation.
swipeDirection.helpDescription: Defines the direction of the swipe movement (e.g LeftToRight, RightToLeft, Both) to display the control defined in the swipeContent aggregation.

inset.description: Defines the indentation of the container. Setting it to true indents the list.
inset.helpDescription: Defines the indentation of the container. Setting it to true indents the list.

growingDirection.description: Defines the direction of the growing feature. If set to Downwards the user has to scroll down to load more items or the growing button is displayed at the bottom. If set to Upwards the user has to scroll up to load more items or the growing button is displayed at the top.
growingDirection.helpDescription: Defines the direction of the growing feature. If set to Downwards the user has to scroll down to load more items or the growing button is displayed at the bottom. noDataText.description: This text is displayed when the control contains no items.

The supported settings are:

sap.m.FlexItemData.description: Holds layout data for a FlexBox|HBox|VBox
sap.m.FlexItemData.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new sap.m.FlexItemData. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getAlignSelf alignSelf} : sap.m.FlexAlignSelf (default: Auto)
    • {@link #getOrder order} : int (default: 0)
    • {@link #getGrowFactor growFactor} : float (default: 0)
    • {@link #getShrinkFactor shrinkFactor} : float (default: 1)
    • {@link #getBaseSize baseSize} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: auto)
    • {@link #getMinHeight minHeight} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: auto)
    • {@link #getMaxHeight maxHeight} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: )
    • {@link #getMinWidth minWidth} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: auto)
    • {@link #getMaxWidth maxWidth} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: )
    • {@link #getStyleClass styleClass} : string (default: )
    • {@link #getBackgroundDesign backgroundDesign} : sap.m.BackgroundDesign (default: Transparent)
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.LayoutData#constructor sap.ui.core.LayoutData} can be used as well.
sap.m.FlexItemData.helpDescription: Holds layout data for a FlexBox|HBox|VBox

sap.m.Tile.description: A tile to be displayed in the tile container. Use this tile as the base class for specialized tile implementations. Use the renderer _addOuterClass methods to add a style class to the main surface of the Tile. In this class set the background color, gradients or background images. Instead of implementing the default render method in the renderer, implement your content HTML in the _renderContent method of the specialized tile.
sap.m.Tile.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new Tile. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getRemovable removable} : boolean (default: true)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:press press} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.m.Tile.helpDescription: A tile to be displayed in the tile container. Use this tile as the base class for specialized tile implementations. Use the renderer _addOuterClass methods to add a style class to the main surface of the Tile. In this class set the background color, gradients or background images. Instead of implementing the default render method in the renderer, implement your content HTML in the _renderContent method of the specialized tile.

sap.m.ObjectAttribute.description: The ObjectAttribute control displays a text field that can be normal or active. The ObjectAttribute fires a press event when the user selects active text.
sap.m.ObjectAttribute.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new ObjectAttribute. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getTitle title} : string
    • {@link #getText text} : string
    • {@link #getActive active} : boolean
    • {@link #getTextDirection textDirection} : sap.ui.core.TextDirection (default: Inherit)
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getCustomContent customContent} : sap.ui.core.Control
  • Events
    • {@link #event:press press} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.m.ObjectAttribute.helpDescription: The ObjectAttribute control displays a text field that can be normal or active. The ObjectAttribute fires a press event when the user selects active text.

customContent.description: When the aggregation is set, it replaces the text, active and textDirection properties. This also ignores the press event. The provided control is displayed as an active link. Note: It will only allow sap.m.Text and sap.m.Link controls.

busyIndicatorSize.description: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. If the size could vary in width and the width could get smaller than 3rem, the sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Auto option could be used. The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.

sap.m.NotificationListGroup.description: The NotificationListItemGroup control is used for grouping NotificationListItems of the same type.
sap.m.NotificationListGroup.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new NotificationListGroup. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getCollapsed collapsed} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getAutoPriority autoPriority} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getShowEmptyGroup showEmptyGroup} : boolean (default: false)
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getItems items} : sap.m.NotificationListItem[] (default)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:onCollapse onCollapse} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.m.NotificationListBase#constructor sap.m.NotificationListBase} can be used as well.
sap.m.NotificationListGroup.helpDescription: The NotificationListItemGroup control is used for grouping NotificationListItems of the same type.

sap.m.TablePersoController.constructorDescription:
The TablePersoController can be used to connect a table that you want to provide a personalization dialog for, with a persistence service such as one provided by the unified shell. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getContentWidth contentWidth} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize
    • {@link #getContentHeight contentHeight} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: 20rem)
    • {@link #getComponentName componentName} : string
    • {@link #getHasGrouping hasGrouping} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getShowSelectAll showSelectAll} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getShowResetAll showResetAll} : boolean (default: true)
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getPersoService persoService} : Object
  • Associations
    • {@link #getTable table} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.m.Table)
    • {@link #getTables tables} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.m.Table)[]
  • Events
    • {@link #event:personalizationsDone personalizationsDone} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor sap.ui.base.ManagedObject} can be used as well.

sap.m.List.description: The List control provides a container for all types of list items. For mobile devices, the recommended limit of list items is 100 to assure proper performance. To improve initial rendering of large lists, use the "growing" feature. Please refer to the SAPUI5 Developer Guide for more information..
sap.m.List.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new List. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getBackgroundDesign backgroundDesign} : sap.m.BackgroundDesign (default: Solid)
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getColumns columns} : sap.m.Column[]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.m.ListBase#constructor sap.m.ListBase} can be used as well.

To improve initial rendering of large lists, use the "growing" feature. Please refer to the SAPUI5 Developer Guide for more information..

rememberSelections.description: If set to true, this control remembers and retains the selection of the items after a binding update has been performed (e.g. sorting, filtering). Note: This feature works only if two-way data binding for the selected property of the item is not used. It also needs to be turned off if the binding context of the item does not always point to the same entry in the model, for example, if the order of the data in the JSONModel is changed.

busyIndicatorSize.description: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. If the size could vary in width and the width could get smaller than 3rem, the sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Auto option could be used. The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.

enableBusyIndicator.description: When this property is set to true, the control will automatically display a busy indicator when it detects that data is being loaded. This busy indicator blocks the interaction with the items until data loading is finished. By default, the busy indicator will be shown after one second. This behavior can be customized by setting the busyIndicatorDelay property.

This busy indicator blocks the interaction with the items until data loading is finished. By default, the busy indicator will be shown after one second. This behavior can be customized by setting the busyIndicatorDelay property.

sap.m.FacetFilterList.description: FacetFilterList represents a list of values for the FacetFilter control.
sap.m.FacetFilterList.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new FacetFilterList. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getTitle title} : string
    • {@link #getWordWrap wordWrap} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getMultiSelect multiSelect} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getActive active} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getEnableCaseInsensitiveSearch enableCaseInsensitiveSearch} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getAllCount allCount} : int
    • {@link #getSequence sequence} : int (default: -1)
    • {@link #getKey key} : string
    • {@link #getShowRemoveFacetIcon showRemoveFacetIcon} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getRetainListSequence retainListSequence} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getDataType dataType} : sap.m.FacetFilterListDataType (default: String)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:listOpen listOpen} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:listClose listClose} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.m.List#constructor sap.m.List} can be used as well.
sap.m.FacetFilterList.helpDescription: FacetFilterList represents a list of values for the FacetFilter control.

sap.m.UploadCollectionParameter.description: Represents a parameter for the UploadCollection.
sap.m.UploadCollectionParameter.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new UploadCollectionParameter. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getName name} : string
    • {@link #getValue value} : string
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Element#constructor sap.ui.core.Element} can be used as well.
sap.m.UploadCollectionParameter.helpDescription: Represents a parameter for the UploadCollection.

sap.m.MaskInput.description: The sap.m.MaskInput control allows users to easily enter data in a certain format and in a fixed-width input (for example: date, time, phone number, credit card number, currency, IP address, MAC address, and others).
sap.m.MaskInput.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new MaskInput. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getPlaceholderSymbol placeholderSymbol} : string (default: _)
    • {@link #getMask mask} : string
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getRules rules} : sap.m.MaskInputRule[]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.m.InputBase#constructor sap.m.InputBase} can be used as well.
sap.m.MaskInput.helpDescription: The sap.m.MaskInput control allows users to easily enter data in a certain format and in a fixed-width input (for example: date, time, phone number, credit card number, currency, IP address, MAC address, and others).

busyIndicatorSize.description: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. If the size could vary in width and the width could get smaller than 3rem, the sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Auto option could be used. The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.

AutoIDs use a unique prefix that must not be used for Ids that the application (or other code) creates. It can be configured option 'autoIDPrefix', see {@link sap.ui.core.Configuration}.

value.description: Defines the value of the control.
value.helpDescription: Defines the value of the control.

mask.description: Mask defined by its characters type (respectively, by its length). You should consider the following important facts: 1. The mask characters normally correspond to an existing rule (one rule per unique char). Characters which don't, are considered immutable characters (for example, the mask '2099', where '9' corresponds to a rule for digits, has the characters '2' and '0' as immutable). 2. Adding a rule corresponding to the placeholderSymbol is not recommended and would lead to an unpredictable behavior. 3. You can use the special escape character '^' called "Caret" prepending a rule character to make it immutable. Use the double escape '^^' if you want to make use of the escape character as a immutable one.
mask.helpDescription: Mask defined by its characters type (respectively, by its length). You should consider the following important facts: 1. Adding a rule corresponding to the placeholderSymbol is not recommended and would lead to an unpredictable behavior. 3. You can use the special escape character '^' called "Caret" prepending a rule character to make it immutable. Use the double escape '^^' if you want to make use of the escape character as a immutable one.

sap.m.Page.description: A container control that holds one whole screen of an application.
sap.m.Page.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new Page. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getTitle title} : string
    • {@link #getTitleLevel titleLevel} : sap.ui.core.TitleLevel (default: Auto)
    • {@link #getShowNavButton showNavButton} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getShowHeader showHeader} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getShowSubHeader showSubHeader} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getNavButtonText navButtonText} : string
    • {@link #getNavButtonTooltip navButtonTooltip} : string
    • {@link #getEnableScrolling enableScrolling} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getIcon icon} : sap.ui.core.URI
    • {@link #getBackgroundDesign backgroundDesign} : sap.m.PageBackgroundDesign (default: Standard)
    • {@link #getNavButtonType navButtonType} : sap.m.ButtonType (default: Back)
    • {@link #getShowFooter showFooter} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getContentOnlyBusy contentOnlyBusy} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getFloatingFooter floatingFooter} : boolean (default: false)
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getContent content} : sap.ui.core.Control[] (default)
    • {@link #getCustomHeader customHeader} : sap.m.IBar
    • {@link #getFooter footer} : sap.m.IBar
    • {@link #getSubHeader subHeader} : sap.m.IBar
    • {@link #getHeaderContent headerContent} : sap.ui.core.Control[]
    • {@link #getLandmarkInfo landmarkInfo} : sap.m.PageAccessibleLandmarkInfo
  • Events
    • {@link #event:navButtonTap navButtonTap} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:navButtonPress navButtonPress} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.m.Page.helpDescription: A container control that holds one whole screen of an application.

customHeader.description: The (optional) custom header of this page. Use this aggregation only when a custom header is constructed where the default header consisting of title text + nav button is not sufficient. If this aggregation is set, the simple properties "title", "showNavButton", "NavButtonText" and "icon" are not used.
customHeader.helpDescription: The (optional) custom header of this page. Use this aggregation only when a custom header is constructed where the default header consisting of title text + nav button is not sufficient. If this aggregation is set, the simple properties "title", "showNavButton", "NavButtonText" and "icon" are not used.

headerContent.description: Controls to be added to the right side of the page header. Usually an application would use Button controls and limit the number to one when the application needs to run on smartphones. There is no automatic overflow handling when the space is insufficient. When a customHeader is used, this aggregation will be ignored.
headerContent.helpDescription: Controls to be added to the right side of the page header. Usually an application would use Button controls and limit the number to one when the application needs to run on smartphones. There is no automatic overflow handling when the space is insufficient. When a customHeader is used, this aggregation will be ignored.

enableScrolling.description:
Enable vertical scrolling of page contents. Page headers and footers are fixed and do not scroll. If set to false, there will be no vertical scrolling at all.

The Page only allows vertical scrolling because horizontal scrolling is discouraged in general for full-page content. If it still needs to be achieved, disable the Page scrolling and use a ScrollContainer as full-page content of the Page. This allows you to freely configure scrolling. It can also be used to create horizontally-scrolling sub-areas of (vertically-scrolling) Pages.
enableScrolling.helpDescription:
Enable vertical scrolling of page contents. Page headers and footers are fixed and do not scroll. If set to false, there will be no vertical scrolling at all.

The Page only allows vertical scrolling because horizontal scrolling is discouraged in general for full-page content. If it still needs to be achieved, disable the Page scrolling and use a ScrollContainer as full-page content of the Page. This allows you to freely configure scrolling. It can also be used to create horizontally-scrolling sub-areas of (vertically-scrolling) Pages.

models.description: A map of model instances to which the object should be attached. The models are keyed by their model name. For the default model, String(undefined) is expected.

visible.description: Whether the control should be visible on the screen. If set to false, a placeholder will be rendered to mark the location of the invisible control in the DOM of the current page. The placeholder will be hidden and have zero dimensions (display: none). See {@link sap.ui.core.RenderManager#writeInvisiblePlaceholderData RenderManager#writeInvisiblePlaceholderData} for details.
visible.helpDescription: Whether the control should be visible on the screen. contentOnlyBusy.description: Decides which area is covered by the local BusyIndicator when page.setBusy() is called. By default the entire page is covered, including headers and footer. When this property is set to "true", only the content area is covered (not header/sub header and footer), which is useful e.g. when there is a SearchField in the sub header and live search continuously updates the content area while the user is still able to type.
contentOnlyBusy.helpDescription: Decides which area is covered by the local BusyIndicator when page.setBusy() is called. By default the entire page is covered, including headers and footer. When this property is set to "true", only the content area is covered (not header/sub header and footer), which is useful e.g. when there is a SearchField in the sub header and live search continuously updates the content area while the user is still able to type.

objectBindings.description: A map of model instances to which the object should be attached. The models are keyed by their model name. For the default model, String(undefined) is expected.

busyIndicatorSize.description: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. If the size could vary in width and the width could get smaller than 3rem, the sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Auto option could be used. The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.
busyIndicatorSize.helpDescription: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. If the size could vary in width and the width could get smaller than 3rem, the sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Auto option could be used. The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.

showHeader.description: Whether this page shall have a header. sap.m.ImageContent.description: This control can be displayed as image content in a tile.
sap.m.ImageContent.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new sap.m.ImageContent control. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getSrc src} : sap.ui.core.URI
    • {@link #getDescription description} : string
  • Aggregations
  • Events
    • {@link #event:press press} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.m.ImageContent.helpDescription: This control can be displayed as image content in a tile.

sap.m.ListItemBase.description: ListItemBase contains the base features of all specific list items.
sap.m.ListItemBase.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new ListItemBase. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getType type} : sap.m.ListType (default: Inactive)
    • {@link #getVisible visible} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getUnread unread} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getSelected selected} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getCounter counter} : int
    • {@link #getHighlight highlight} : sap.ui.core.MessageType (default: None)
  • Associations
    • {@link #getAriaLabelledBy ariaLabelledBy} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Control)[]
  • Events
    • {@link #event:tap tap} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:detailTap detailTap} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:press press} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:detailPress detailPress} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.m.ListItemBase.helpDescription: ListItemBase contains the base features of all specific list items.

sap.m.Column.description: The sap.m.Column allows to define column specific properties that will be applied when rendering the sap.m.Table.
sap.m.Column.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new Column. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getWidth width} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize
    • {@link #getHAlign hAlign} : sap.ui.core.TextAlign (default: Begin)
    • {@link #getVAlign vAlign} : sap.ui.core.VerticalAlign (default: Inherit)
    • {@link #getStyleClass styleClass} : string
    • {@link #getVisible visible} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getMinScreenWidth minScreenWidth} : string
    • {@link #getDemandPopin demandPopin} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getPopinHAlign popinHAlign} : sap.ui.core.TextAlign (default: Begin)
    • {@link #getPopinDisplay popinDisplay} : sap.m.PopinDisplay (default: Block)
    • {@link #getMergeDuplicates mergeDuplicates} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getMergeFunctionName mergeFunctionName} : string (default: getText)
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getHeader header} : sap.ui.core.Control (default)
    • {@link #getFooter footer} : sap.ui.core.Control
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Element#constructor sap.ui.core.Element} can be used as well.
sap.m.Column.helpDescription: The sap.m.Column allows to define column specific properties that will be applied when rendering the sap.m.Table.

NOTE: Control with a "textAlign" property inherits the horizontal alignment.

styleClass.description: CSS class name for column contents(header, cells and footer of column). This property can be used for different column styling. If column is shown as pop-in then this class name is applied to related pop-in row.
styleClass.helpDescription: CSS class name for column contents(header, cells and footer of column). This property can be used for different column styling. If column is shown as pop-in then this class name is applied to related pop-in row.

minScreenWidth.description:
By default column is always shown. If you set this property, control checks the minimum width of the screen to show or hide this column. As you can give specific CSS sizes(e.g: "480px" or "40em"), you can also use sap.m.ScreenSize enumeration(e.g: "Phone", "Tablet", "Desktop", "Small", "Medium", "Large", ....).

sap.m.Column.MediaQuery1->Range1 = 199

This property can be used for responsive design. e.g: "40em"(or "640px" or "Tablet") setting shows this column in iPad(and Desktop) but hides in iPhone. Please also see "demandPopin" property

vAlign.helpDescription: Vertical alignment of the cells in a column. Possible values are "Inherit", "Top", "Middle", "Bottom" This property does not affect the vertical alignment of header and footer.

Note: You can pass one string parameter to given function after "#" sign. e.g. "data#myparameter"
