sap.m.ResponsivePopover.description: This control acts responsively to the type of device. It acts as a sap.m.Popover on desktop and tablet, while on phone it acts as a sap.m.Dialog with stretch set to true.
sap.m.ResponsivePopover.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new ResponsivePopover. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getPlacement placement} : sap.m.PlacementType (default: Right)
    • {@link #getShowHeader showHeader} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getTitle title} : string
    • {@link #getIcon icon} : sap.ui.core.URI
    • {@link #getModal modal} : boolean
    • {@link #getOffsetX offsetX} : int
    • {@link #getOffsetY offsetY} : int
    • {@link #getShowArrow showArrow} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getContentWidth contentWidth} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize
    • {@link #getContentHeight contentHeight} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize
    • {@link #getHorizontalScrolling horizontalScrolling} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getVerticalScrolling verticalScrolling} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getShowCloseButton showCloseButton} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getResizable resizable} : boolean (default: false)
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getContent content} : sap.ui.core.Control[]
    • {@link #getCustomHeader customHeader} : sap.m.IBar
    • {@link #getSubHeader subHeader} : sap.m.IBar
    • {@link #getBeginButton beginButton} : sap.m.Button
    • {@link #getEndButton endButton} : sap.m.Button
  • Associations
    • {@link #getInitialFocus initialFocus} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Control)
    • {@link #getAriaLabelledBy ariaLabelledBy} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Control)[]
    • {@link #getAriaDescribedBy ariaDescribedBy} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Control)[]
  • Events
    • {@link #event:beforeOpen beforeOpen} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:afterOpen afterOpen} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:beforeClose beforeClose} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:afterClose afterClose} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.m.ResponsivePopover.helpDescription: This control acts responsively to the type of device. It acts as a sap.m.Popover on desktop and tablet, while on phone it acts as a sap.m.Dialog with stretch set to true.

sap.m.RadioButton.description:
RadioButton is a control similar to CheckBox, but it allows the user to choose only one of the predefined set of options.

Usually, RadioButton is used in a group with other RadioButtons (with the groupName property or by using sap.m.RadioButtonGroup), thus providing a limited choice for the user. An event is triggered when the user makes a change of the selection.
sap.m.RadioButton.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new RadioButton. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getEnabled enabled} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getSelected selected} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getGroupName groupName} : string (default: sapMRbDefaultGroup)
    • {@link #getText text} : string
    • {@link #getTextDirection textDirection} : sap.ui.core.TextDirection (default: Inherit)
    • {@link #getWidth width} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: )
    • {@link #getUseEntireWidth useEntireWidth} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getActiveHandling activeHandling} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getEditable editable} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getValueState valueState} : sap.ui.core.ValueState (default: None)
    • {@link #getTextAlign textAlign} : sap.ui.core.TextAlign (default: Begin)
  • Associations
    • {@link #getAriaDescribedBy ariaDescribedBy} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Control)[]

sap.m.RadioButton.helpDescription:
RadioButton is a control similar to CheckBox, but it allows the user to choose only one of the predefined set of options.

Usually, RadioButton is used in a group with other RadioButtons (with the groupName property or by using sap.m.RadioButtonGroup), thus providing a limited choice for the user. An event is triggered when the user makes a change of the selection.

sap.m.SplitContainer.description:
SplitContainer maintains two NavContainers if running on tablet or desktop and one NavContainer - on phone. The display of the master NavContainer depends on the portrait/landscape mode of the device and the mode of SplitContainer.

NOTE: This control must be rendered as a full screen control in order to make the show/hide master area work properly.
sap.m.SplitContainer.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new SplitContainer. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getDefaultTransitionNameDetail defaultTransitionNameDetail} : string (default: slide)
    • {@link #getDefaultTransitionNameMaster defaultTransitionNameMaster} : string (default: slide)
    • {@link #getMode mode} : sap.m.SplitAppMode (default: ShowHideMode)
    • {@link #getMasterButtonText masterButtonText} : string
    • {@link #getBackgroundColor backgroundColor} : string
    • {@link #getBackgroundImage backgroundImage} : sap.ui.core.URI
    • {@link #getBackgroundRepeat backgroundRepeat} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getBackgroundOpacity backgroundOpacity} : float (default: 1)
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getMasterPages masterPages} : sap.ui.core.Control[]
    • {@link #getDetailPages detailPages} : sap.ui.core.Control[]
  • Associations
    • {@link #getInitialDetail initialDetail} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Control)
    • {@link #getInitialMaster initialMaster} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Control)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:masterNavigate masterNavigate} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:afterMasterNavigate afterMasterNavigate} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:masterButton masterButton} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:beforeMasterOpen beforeMasterOpen} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:afterMasterOpen afterMasterOpen} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:beforeMasterClose beforeMasterClose} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:afterMasterClose afterMasterClose} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:detailNavigate detailNavigate} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:afterDetailNavigate afterDetailNavigate} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.m.SplitContainer.helpDescription:
SplitContainer maintains two NavContainers if running on tablet or desktop and one NavContainer - on phone. The display of the master NavContainer depends on the portrait/landscape mode of the device and the mode of SplitContainer.

NOTE: This control must be rendered as a full screen control in order to make the show/hide master area work properly.

backgroundColor.description: Determines the background color of the SplitContainer. If set, this color overrides the default one, which is defined by the theme (should only be used when really required). Any configured background image will be placed above this colored background, but any theme adaptation in the Theme Designer will override this setting. Use the backgroundRepeat property to define whether this image should be stretched to cover the complete SplitContainer or whether it should be tiled.

defaultTransitionNameMaster.description: Determines the type of the transition/animation to apply when to() is called, without defining the transition to use. The default is "slide", other options are "fade", "show", and the names of any registered custom transitions.

backgroundOpacity.description: Defines the opacity of the background image - between 0 (fully transparent) and 1 (fully opaque). This can be used to improve the content visibility by making the background image partly transparent.
backgroundOpacity.helpDescription: Defines the opacity of the background image - between 0 (fully transparent) and 1 (fully opaque). This can be used to improve the content visibility by making the background image partly transparent.

mode.description: Defines whether the master page will always be displayed (in portrait and landscape mode - StretchCompressMode), or if it should be hidden when in portrait mode (ShowHideMode). Default is ShowHideMode. Other possible values are Hide (Master is always hidden) and Popover (master is displayed in popover).

masterButtonText.description: Determines the text displayed in master button, which has a default value "Navigation". This text is only displayed in iOS platform and the icon from the current page in detail area is displayed in the master button for the other platforms. The master button is shown/hidden depending on the orientation of the device and whether the master area is opened or not. SplitContainer manages the show/hide of the master button by itself only when the pages added to the detail area are sap.m.Page with built-in header or sap.m.Page with built-in header, which is wrapped by one or several sap.ui.core.mvc.View. Otherwise, the show/hide of master button needs to be managed by the application.
masterButtonText.helpDescription: Determines the text displayed in master button, which has a default value "Navigation". This text is only displayed in iOS platform and the icon from the current page in detail area is displayed in the master button for the other platforms. The master button is shown/hidden depending on the orientation of the device and whether the master area is opened or not. SplitContainer manages the show/hide of the master button by itself only when the pages added to the detail area are sap.m.Page with built-in header or sap.m.Page with built-in header, which is wrapped by one or several sap.ui.core.mvc.View. Otherwise, the show/hide of master button needs to be managed by the application.

sap.m.UploadCollectionItem.description: Items provide information about the uploaded files.
sap.m.UploadCollectionItem.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new UploadCollectionItem Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getContributor contributor} : string
    • {@link #getDocumentId documentId} : string
    • {@link #getFileName fileName} : string
    • {@link #getFileSize fileSize} : float
    • {@link #getMimeType mimeType} : string
    • {@link #getThumbnailUrl thumbnailUrl} : string
    • {@link #getUploadedDate uploadedDate} : string
    • {@link #getUrl url} : string
    • {@link #getEnableEdit enableEdit} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getEnableDelete enableDelete} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getVisibleEdit visibleEdit} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getVisibleDelete visibleDelete} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getAriaLabelForPicture ariaLabelForPicture} : string
    • {@link #getSelected selected} : boolean (default: false)
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getAttributes attributes} : sap.m.ObjectAttribute[] (default)
    • {@link #getStatuses statuses} : sap.m.ObjectStatus[]
    • {@link #getMarkers markers} : sap.m.ObjectMarker[]
  • Associations
    • {@link #getFileUploader fileUploader} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.unified.FileUploader)
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Element#constructor sap.ui.core.Element} can be used as well.
sap.m.UploadCollectionItem.helpDescription: Items provide information about the uploaded files.

attributes.description:
Attributes of an uploaded item, for example, 'Uploaded By', 'Uploaded On', 'File Size' attributes are displayed after an item has been uploaded. Additionally, the Active property of sap.m.ObjectAttribute is supported.
Note that if one of the deprecated properties contributor, fileSize or UploadedDate is filled in addition to this attribute, two attributes with the same title are displayed as these properties get displayed as an attribute. Example: An application passes the property ‘contributor’ with the value ‘A’ and the aggregation attributes ‘contributor’: ‘B’. As a result, the attributes ‘contributor’:’A’ and ‘contributor’:’B’ are displayed. To make sure the title does not appear twice, check if one of the properties is filled.

sap.m.DateTimePicker.description:
Overview

The {@link sap.m.DateTimePicker} control allows users to select date and time values in a combined input. It consists of two parts: the input field and the date/time picker.

Note: The {@link sap.ui.unified.Calendar} is used internally only if the DateTimePicker is opened (not used for the initial rendering). If the sap.ui.unified library is not loaded before the DateTimePicker is opened, it will be loaded upon opening. This could lead to a waiting time when the DateTimePicker is opened for the first time. To prevent this, apps using the DateTimePicker should also load the sap.ui.unified library.

Usage

Use this control if you need a combined date and time input control.
Don't use it if you want to use either a date or a time value. In this case, use the {@link sap.m.DatePicker} or the {@link sap.m.TimePicker} controls instead.

The user can enter a date by:
  • Using the calendar or a time selector that opens in a popup
  • Typing it in directly in the input field
On app level, there are two options to provide a date for the DateTimePicker - as a string to the value property or as a JavaScript Date object to the dateValue property (only one of these properties should be used at a time):
  • Use the value property if you want to bind the DateTimePicker to a model using the sap.ui.model.type.DateTime
  • Use the value property if the date is provided as a string from the backend or inside the app (for example, as ABAP type DATS field)
  • Use the dateValue property if the date is already provided as a JavaScript Date object or you want to work with a JavaScript Date object
Formatting

All formatting and parsing of dates from and to strings is done using the {@link sap.ui.core.format.DateFormat}. If a date is entered by typing it into the input field, it must fit to the used date format and locale.

Supported format options are pattern-based on Unicode LDML Date Format notation. See {@link http://unicode.org/reports/tr35/#Date_Field_Symbol_Table}

For example, if the valueFormat is "yyyy-MM-dd-HH-mm-ss", the displayFormat is "MMM d, y, HH:mm:ss", and the used locale is English, a valid value string is "2015-07-30-10-30-15", which leads to an output of "Jul 30, 2015, 10:30:15".

If no placeholder is set to the DateTimePicker, the used displayFormat is displayed as a placeholder. If another placeholder is needed, it must be set.

Note: If the string does NOT match the displayFormat (from user input) or the valueFormat (on app level), the {@link sap.ui.core.format.DateFormat} makes an attempt to parse it based on the locale settings. For more information, see the respective documentation in the API Reference.

Responsive behavior

The DateTimePicker is responsive and fully adapts to all devices. For larger screens, such as tablet or desktop, it opens as a popover. For mobile devices, it opens in full screen.
sap.m.DateTimePicker.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new DateTimePicker. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Aggregations
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.m.DatePicker#constructor sap.m.DatePicker} can be used as well.

displayFormatType.helpDescription: Displays date in this given type in input field. Default value is taken from locale settings. Accepted are values of sap.ui.core.CalendarType or an empty string. valueFormat.description: The date string expected and returned in the value property uses this format. By default the short format of the used locale is used. Supported format options are pattern-based on Unicode LDML Date Format notation. {@link http://unicode.org/reports/tr35/#Date_Field_Symbol_Table} For example, if the date string represents an ABAP DATS type, the format should be "yyyyMMdd". Note: If data binding on value property with type sap.ui.model.type.Date is used, this property will be ignored. The format defined in the binding will be used.

Note: If data binding on value property with type sap.ui.model.type.Date is used, this property will be ignored. The format defined in the binding will be used.

displayFormat.description: The date is displayed in the input field using this format. By default, the medium format of the used locale is used. Supported format options are pattern-based on Unicode LDML Date Format notation. {@link http://unicode.org/reports/tr35/#Date_Field_Symbol_Table} Note: If you use data binding on the value property with type sap.ui.model.type.Date this property will be ignored. The format defined in the binding will be used.

sap.m.SelectList.description: The sap.m.SelectList displays a list of items that allows the user to select an item.
sap.m.SelectList.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new sap.m.SelectList. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getEnabled enabled} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getWidth width} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: auto)
    • {@link #getMaxWidth maxWidth} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: 100%)
    • {@link #getSelectedKey selectedKey} : string (default: )
    • {@link #getSelectedItemId selectedItemId} : string (default: )
    • {@link #getShowSecondaryValues showSecondaryValues} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getKeyboardNavigationMode keyboardNavigationMode} : sap.m.SelectListKeyboardNavigationMode (default: Delimited)
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getItems items} : sap.ui.core.Item[] (default)
  • Associations
    • {@link #getSelectedItem selectedItem} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Item)
    • {@link #getAriaLabelledBy ariaLabelledBy} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Control)[]
  • Events
    • {@link #event:selectionChange selectionChange} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:itemPress itemPress} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.m.SelectList.helpDescription: The sap.m.SelectList displays a list of items that allows the user to select an item.

initialPage.description:
This association can be used to define which page is displayed initially. If the given page does not exist or no page is given, the first page which has been added is considered as initial page. This value should be set initially and not set/modified while the application is running.

This could be used not only for the initial display, but also if the user wants to navigate "up to top", so this page serves as a sort of "home/root page".

This association can be used to define which page is displayed initially. If the given page does not exist or no page is given, the first page which has been added is considered as initial page. This value should be set initially and not set/modified while the application is running.

This could be used not only for the initial display, but also if the user wants to navigate "up to top", so this page serves as a sort of "home/root page".

sap.m.NavContainer.description:
The NavContainer control handles hierarchic navigation between Pages or other fullscreen controls.

All children of this control will receive navigation events like {@link sap.m.NavContainerChild#beforeShow beforeShow}, they are documented in the pseudo interface {@link sap.m.NavContainerChild sap.m.NavContainerChild}
sap.m.NavContainer.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new NavContainer. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getAutoFocus autoFocus} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getHeight height} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: 100%)
    • {@link #getWidth width} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: 100%)
    • {@link #getVisible visible} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getDefaultTransitionName defaultTransitionName} : string (default: slide)
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getPages pages} : sap.ui.core.Control[] (default)
  • Associations
    • {@link #getInitialPage initialPage} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Control)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:navigate navigate} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:afterNavigate afterNavigate} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.m.NavContainer.helpDescription:
The NavContainer control handles hierarchic navigation between Pages or other fullscreen controls.

All children of this control will receive navigation events like {@link sap.m.NavContainerChild#beforeShow beforeShow}, they are documented in the pseudo interface {@link sap.m.NavContainerChild sap.m.NavContainerChild}

layoutData.description: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.
layoutData.helpDescription: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.

pages.description:
The content entities between which this NavContainer navigates. These can be of type sap.m.Page, sap.ui.core.View, sap.m.Carousel or any other control with fullscreen/page semantics.

These aggregated controls will receive navigation events like {@link sap.m.NavContainerChild#beforeShow beforeShow}, they are documented in the pseudo interface {@link sap.m.NavContainerChild sap.m.NavContainerChild}
pages.helpDescription:
The content entities between which this NavContainer navigates. These can be of type sap.m.Page, sap.ui.core.View, sap.m.Carousel or any other control with fullscreen/page semantics.

These aggregated controls will receive navigation events like {@link sap.m.NavContainerChild#beforeShow beforeShow}, they are documented in the pseudo interface {@link sap.m.NavContainerChild sap.m.NavContainerChild}

busyIndicatorSize.description: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. If the size could vary in width and the width could get smaller than 3rem, the sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Auto option could be used. The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.
busyIndicatorSize.helpDescription: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. If the size could vary in width and the width could get smaller than 3rem, the sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Auto option could be used. The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.

autoFocus.description: Determines whether the initial focus is set automatically on first rendering and after navigating to a new page. This is useful when on touch devices the keyboard pops out due to the focus being automatically set on an input field. If necessary the "afterShow" event can be used to focus another element.
autoFocus.helpDescription: Determines whether the initial focus is set automatically on first rendering and after navigating to a new page. This is useful when on touch devices the keyboard pops out due to the focus being automatically set on an input field. If necessary the "afterShow" event can be used to focus another element.

defaultTransitionName.description: The type of the transition/animation to apply when "to()" is called without defining a transition type to use. The default is "slide". Other options are: "fade", "flip" and "show" - and the names of any registered custom transitions.
defaultTransitionName.helpDescription: The type of the transition/animation to apply when "to()" is called without defining a transition type to use. The default is "slide". Other options are: "fade", "flip" and "show" - and the names of any registered custom transitions.

busyIndicatorDelay.helpDescription: The delay in milliseconds, after which the busy indicator will show up for this control.

busy.description: Whether the control is currently in busy state.
busy.helpDescription: Whether the control is currently in busy state.

fieldGroupIds.description: The IDs of a logical field group that this control belongs to. All fields in a logical field group should share the same fieldGroupId. Once a logical field group is left, the validateFieldGroup event is raised. See {@link sap.ui.core.Control#attachValidateFieldGroup}.

Once a logical field group is left, the validateFieldGroup event is raised. See {@link sap.ui.core.Control#attachValidateFieldGroup}.

navigate.name: navigate

eventParams.oControlEvent.getParameters.isTo: type: boolean, description: Whether this is a forward navigation, triggered by "to()".
eventParams.oControlEvent.getParameters.isBackToTop: type: boolean, description: Whether this is a navigation to the root page, triggered by "backToTop()".
eventParams.oControlEvent.getParameters.to: type: sap.ui.core.Control, description: The page which will be shown after the current navigation.
eventParams.oControlEvent.getParameters.direction: type: string, description: How the navigation was triggered, possible values are "to", "back", "backToPage", and "backToTop".
eventParams.oControlEvent.getParameters.fromId: type: string, description: The ID of the page which was shown before the current navigation.
eventParams.oControlEvent.getParameters.isBack: type: boolean, description: Whether this is a back navigation, triggered by "back()".
eventParams.oControlEvent.getParameters.toId: type: string, description: The ID of the page which will be shown after the current navigation.
eventParams.oControlEvent.getParameters.from: type: sap.ui.core.Control, description: The page which was shown before the current navigation.
eventParams.oControlEvent.getParameters.isBackToPage: type: boolean, description: Whether this was a navigation to a specific page, triggered by "backToPage()".
eventParams.oControlEvent.getParameters.firstTime: type: boolean, description: Whether the "to" page (more precisely: a control with the ID of the page which is currently navigated to) has not been shown/navigated to before.

navigate.description: The event is fired when navigation between two pages has been triggered. The transition (if any) to the new page has not started yet. This event can be aborted by the application with preventDefault(), which means that there will be no navigation.
navigate.helpDescription: The event is fired when navigation between two pages has been triggered. The transition (if any) to the new page has not started yet. This event can be aborted by the application with preventDefault(), which means that there will be no navigation.
navigate.type: fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]

afterNavigate.name: afterNavigate
afterNavigate.description: The event is fired when navigation between two pages has completed. In case of animated transitions this event is fired with some delay after the "navigate" event.
afterNavigate.helpDescription: The event is fired when navigation between two pages has completed. In case of animated transitions this event is fired with some delay after the "navigate" event.
afterNavigate.type: fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]

sap.m.MenuItem.description: The MenuItem control is used for creating items for the sap.m.Menu. It is derived from a core sap.ui.core.Item.
sap.m.MenuItem.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new MenuItem. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getIcon icon} : string
    • {@link #getVisible visible} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getStartsSection startsSection} : boolean (default: false)
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getItems items} : sap.m.MenuItem[] (default)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:press press} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:propertyChanged propertyChanged} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:aggregationChanged aggregationChanged} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Item#constructor sap.ui.core.Item} can be used as well.
sap.m.MenuItem.helpDescription: The MenuItem control is used for creating items for the sap.m.Menu. It is derived from a core sap.ui.core.Item.

sap.m.SelectDialog.description:
A SelectDialog is a dialog containing a list, search functionality to filter it and a confirmation/cancel button. The control can be used when the user should select one or multiple items out of many.

The list used in the SelectDialog is a growing list and can be filled with a any kind of list item. The search field triggers the events "search" and "liveChange" where a filter function can be applied to the list binding.

After selecting an item in single selection mode or after confirming in multi selection mode, the dialog will be closed and the event "confirm" is fired with the items that have been selected. By default, the selection will also be reset to allow for a new selection when opening the dialog again.

When cancelling the selection, the event "change" will be fired and the selection is restored to the state when the dialog was opened.

NOTE: The growing functionality of the list does not support two-way Binding, so if you use this control with a JSON model make sure the binding mode is set to "OneWay" and that you update the selection model manually with the items passed in the "confirm" event.
sap.m.SelectDialog.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new SelectDialog. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getTitle title} : string
    • {@link #getNoDataText noDataText} : string
    • {@link #getMultiSelect multiSelect} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getGrowingThreshold growingThreshold} : int
    • {@link #getContentWidth contentWidth} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize
    • {@link #getRememberSelections rememberSelections} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getContentHeight contentHeight} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getItems items} : sap.m.ListItemBase[] (default)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:confirm confirm} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:search search} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:liveChange liveChange} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:cancel cancel} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.m.SelectDialog.helpDescription:
A SelectDialog is a dialog containing a list, search functionality to filter it and a confirmation/cancel button. The control can be used when the user should select one or multiple items out of many.

The list used in the SelectDialog is a growing list and can be filled with a any kind of list item. The search field triggers the events "search" and "liveChange" where a filter function can be applied to the list binding.

After selecting an item in single selection mode or after confirming in multi selection mode, the dialog will be closed and the event "confirm" is fired with the items that have been selected. By default, the selection will also be reset to allow for a new selection when opening the dialog again.

When cancelling the selection, the event "change" will be fired and the selection is restored to the state when the dialog was opened.

NOTE: The growing functionality of the list does not support two-way Binding, so if you use this control with a JSON model make sure the binding mode is set to "OneWay" and that you update the selection model manually with the items passed in the "confirm" event.

sap.m.SegmentedButtonItem.description: The SegmentedButtonItem control is used for creating buttons for the sap.m.SegmentedButton. It is derived from a core sap.ui.core.Item.
sap.m.SegmentedButtonItem.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new SegmentedButtonItem. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getIcon icon} : string
    • {@link #getVisible visible} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getWidth width} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize
  • Events
    • {@link #event:press press} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Item#constructor sap.ui.core.Item} can be used as well.
sap.m.SegmentedButtonItem.helpDescription: The SegmentedButtonItem control is used for creating buttons for the sap.m.SegmentedButton. It is derived from a core sap.ui.core.Item.

initialPage.description:
This association can be used to define which page is displayed initially. If the given page does not exist or no page is given, the first page which has been added is considered as initial page. This value should be set initially and not set/modified while the application is running.

This could be used not only for the initial display, but also if the user wants to navigate "up to top", so this page serves as a sort of "home/root page".
initialPage.helpDescription:
This association can be used to define which page is displayed initially. If the given page does not exist or no page is given, the first page which has been added is considered as initial page. This value should be set initially and not set/modified while the application is running.

This could be used not only for the initial display, but also if the user wants to navigate "up to top", so this page serves as a sort of "home/root page".

sap.m.App.description: App is the root element of a UI5 mobile application. It inherits from NavContainer and thus provides its navigation capabilities. It also adds certain header tags to the HTML page which are considered useful for mobile apps.
sap.m.App.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new App. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getHomeIcon homeIcon} : any
    • {@link #getBackgroundColor backgroundColor} : string
    • {@link #getBackgroundImage backgroundImage} : sap.ui.core.URI
    • {@link #getBackgroundRepeat backgroundRepeat} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getBackgroundOpacity backgroundOpacity} : float (default: 1)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:orientationChange orientationChange} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.m.NavContainer#constructor sap.m.NavContainer} can be used as well.
sap.m.App.helpDescription: App is the root element of a UI5 mobile application. It inherits from NavContainer and thus provides its navigation capabilities. It also adds certain header tags to the HTML page which are considered useful for mobile apps.

layoutData.helpDescription: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.

pages.description:
The content entities between which this NavContainer navigates. These can be of type sap.m.Page, sap.ui.core.View, sap.m.Carousel or any other control with fullscreen/page semantics.

These aggregated controls will receive navigation events like {@link sap.m.NavContainerChild#beforeShow beforeShow}, they are documented in the pseudo interface {@link sap.m.NavContainerChild sap.m.NavContainerChild}

backgroundColor.description: Background color of the App. If set, this color will override the default background defined by the theme. So this should only be set when really required. Any configured background image will be placed above this colored background. But any theme adaptation in the Theme Designer will override this setting. Use the "backgroundRepeat" property to define whether this image should be stretched to cover the complete App or whether it should be tiled.

busyIndicatorSize.description: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. If the size could vary in width and the width could get smaller than 3rem, the sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Auto option could be used. The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.
busyIndicatorSize.helpDescription: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. If the size could vary in width and the width could get smaller than 3rem, the sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Auto option could be used. The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.

backgroundImage.description: Background image of the App. If set, this image will override the default background defined by the theme. So this should only be set when really required. This background image will be placed above any color set for the background. But any theme adaptation in the Theme Designer will override this image setting. Use the "backgroundRepeat" property to define whether this image should be stretched to cover the complete App or whether it should be tiled.
backgroundImage.helpDescription: Background image of the App. If set, this image will override the default background defined by the theme. So this should only be set when really required. This background image will be placed above any color set for the background. But any theme adaptation in the Theme Designer will override this image setting. Use the "backgroundRepeat" property to define whether this image should be stretched to cover the complete App or whether it should be tiled.

backgroundOpacity.description: Opacity of the background image. The opacity can be set between 0 (fully transparent) and 1 fully opaque). This can be used to make the application content better readable by making the background image partly transparent.
backgroundOpacity.helpDescription: Opacity of the background image. The opacity can be set between 0 (fully transparent) and 1 fully opaque). This can be used to make the application content better readable by making the background image partly transparent.

autoFocus.description: Determines whether the initial focus is set automatically on first rendering and after navigating to a new page. This is useful when on touch devices the keyboard pops out due to the focus being automatically set on an input field. If necessary the "afterShow" event can be used to focus another element.

width.helpDescription: The width of the NavContainer. Can be changed when the NavContainer should not cover the whole available area.

homeIcon.description:
The icon to be displayed on the home screen of iOS devices after the user does "add to home screen".

Note that only the first attempt to set the homeIcon will be executed, subsequent settings are ignored.

This icon must be in PNG format. The property can either hold the URL of one single icon which is used for all devices (and possibly scaled, which looks not perfect), or an object holding icon URLs for the different required sizes.

A desktop icon (used for bookmarks and overriding the favicon) can also be configured. This requires an object to be given and the "icon" property of this object then defines the desktop bookmark icon. For this icon, PNG is not supported by Internet Explorer. The ICO format is supported by all browsers. ICO is also preferred for this desktop icon setting because the file can contain different images for different resolutions.

One example is:

app.setHomeIcon({ 'phone':'phone-icon.png', 'phone@2':'phone-retina.png', 'tablet':'tablet-icon.png', 'tablet@2':'tablet-retina.png', 'icon':'desktop.ico' });

The respective image sizes are 57/114 px for the phone and 72/144 px for the tablet. If an object is given but one of the sizes is not given, the largest given icon will be used for this size.

On Android these icons may or may not be used by the device. Apparently chances can be improved by adding glare effect and rounded corners, setting the file name so it ends with "-precomposed.png" and setting the "homeIconPrecomposed" property to "true".
homeIcon.helpDescription:
The icon to be displayed on the home screen of iOS devices after the user does "add to home screen".

Note that only the first attempt to set the homeIcon will be executed, subsequent settings are ignored.

This icon must be in PNG format. The property can either hold the URL of one single icon which is used for all devices (and possibly scaled, which looks not perfect), or an object holding icon URLs for the different required sizes.

A desktop icon (used for bookmarks and overriding the favicon) can also be configured. This requires an object to be given and the "icon" property of this object then defines the desktop bookmark icon. For this icon, PNG is not supported by Internet Explorer. The ICO format is supported by all browsers. ICO is also preferred for this desktop icon setting because the file can contain different images for different resolutions.

One example is:

app.setHomeIcon({ 'phone':'phone-icon.png', 'phone@2':'phone-retina.png', 'tablet':'tablet-icon.png', 'tablet@2':'tablet-retina.png', 'icon':'desktop.ico' });

The respective image sizes are 57/114 px for the phone and 72/144 px for the tablet. If an object is given but one of the sizes is not given, the largest given icon will be used for this size.

On Android these icons may or may not be used by the device. Apparently chances can be improved by adding glare effect and rounded corners, setting the file name so it ends with "-precomposed.png" and setting the "homeIconPrecomposed" property to "true".

sap.m.PlanningCalendarView.description: View of the {@link sap.m.PlanningCalendar}. The PlanningCalendarView defines the type of the intervals (hours, days, months) and how many intervals are displayed.
sap.m.PlanningCalendarView.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new PlanningCalendarView. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getKey key} : string
    • {@link #getIntervalType intervalType} : sap.ui.unified.CalendarIntervalType (default: Hour)
    • {@link #getDescription description} : string
    • {@link #getIntervalsS intervalsS} : int (default: 6)
    • {@link #getIntervalsM intervalsM} : int (default: 8)
    • {@link #getIntervalsL intervalsL} : int (default: 12)
    • {@link #getShowSubIntervals showSubIntervals} : boolean (default: false)
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Element#constructor sap.ui.core.Element} can be used as well.
sap.m.PlanningCalendarView.helpDescription: View of the {@link sap.m.PlanningCalendar}. The PlanningCalendarView defines the type of the intervals (hours, days, months) and how many intervals are displayed.

If set, subintervals are displayed as lines in the rows.

  • Hour subintervals for interval types Day, Week and OneMonth.
  • Day subintervals for interval type Month.

sap.m.CheckBox.description: The CheckBox control allows the user to select one or multiple items from a list. To select each item the user has to select the square box in front of it.
sap.m.CheckBox.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new CheckBox. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getSelected selected} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getEnabled enabled} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getName name} : string
    • {@link #getText text} : string
    • {@link #getTextDirection textDirection} : sap.ui.core.TextDirection (default: Inherit)
    • {@link #getTextAlign textAlign} : sap.ui.core.TextAlign (default: Begin)
    • {@link #getWidth width} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: )
    • {@link #getActiveHandling activeHandling} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getEditable editable} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getValueState valueState} : sap.ui.core.ValueState (default: None)
  • Aggregations
  • Associations
    • {@link #getAriaDescribedBy ariaDescribedBy} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Control)[]
    • {@link #getAriaLabelledBy ariaLabelledBy} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Control)[]

sap.m.MultiComboBox.description: The MultiComboBox control provides a list box with items and a text field allowing the user to either type a value directly into the control or choose from the list of existing items.
sap.m.MultiComboBox.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new MultiComboBox. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getSelectedKeys selectedKeys} : string[] (default: [])
  • Associations
    • {@link #getSelectedItems selectedItems} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Item)[]
  • Events
    • {@link #event:selectionChange selectionChange} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:selectionFinish selectionFinish} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.m.ComboBoxBase#constructor sap.m.ComboBoxBase} can be used as well.

loadItems.name: loadItems
loadItems.description: This event is fired when the end user clicks the combo box button to open the dropdown list and the data used to display items is not already loaded. Alternatively, it is fired after the user moves the cursor to the combo box text field and perform an action that requires data to be loaded. For example, pressing F4 to open the dropdown list or typing something in the text field fires the event. Note: Use this feature in performance critical scenarios only. Loading the data lazily (on demand) to defer initialization has several implications for the end user experience. For example, the busy indicator has to be shown while the items are being loaded and assistive technology software also has to announce the state changes (which may be confusing for some screen reader users). Note: Currently the sap.m.MultiComboBox does not support this event.
loadItems.helpDescription: This event is fired when the end user clicks the combo box button to open the dropdown list and the data used to display items is not already loaded. Alternatively, it is fired after the user moves the cursor to the combo box text field and perform an action that requires data to be loaded. For example, pressing F4 to open the dropdown list or typing something in the text field fires the event. Note: Use this feature in performance critical scenarios only. Loading the data lazily (on demand) to defer initialization has several implications for the end user experience. For example, the busy indicator has to be shown while the items are being loaded and assistive technology software also has to announce the state changes (which may be confusing for some screen reader users). Note: Currently the sap.m.MultiComboBox does not support this event.
loadItems.type: fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]

busy.description: Whether the control is currently in busy state.
busy.helpDescription: Whether the control is currently in busy state.

fieldGroupIds.description: The IDs of a logical field group that this control belongs to. All fields in a logical field group should share the same fieldGroupId. Once a logical field group is left, the validateFieldGroup event is raised. See {@link sap.ui.core.Control#attachValidateFieldGroup}.

selected.description: Defines the selected state of the list items. Note: Binding the selected property in single selection modes may cause unwanted results if you have more than one selected items in your binding.
selected.helpDescription: Defines the selected state of the list items. Note: Binding the selected property in single selection modes may cause unwanted results if you have more than one selected items in your binding.

eventParams.oControlEvent.getParameters.isTo: type: boolean, description: Determines whether this is a forward navigation, triggered by to().
eventParams.oControlEvent.getParameters.isBackToTop: type: boolean, description: Determines whether this is a navigation to the root page, triggered by backToTop().
eventParams.oControlEvent.getParameters.to: type: sap.ui.core.Control, description: The page, which will be displayed after the current navigation.
eventParams.oControlEvent.getParameters.direction: type: string, description: Determines how the navigation was triggered, possible values are "to", "back", "backToPage", and "backToTop".
eventParams.oControlEvent.getParameters.fromId: type: string, description: The ID of the page, which was displayed before the current navigation.
eventParams.oControlEvent.getParameters.isBack: type: boolean, description: Determines whether this is a back navigation, triggered by back().
eventParams.oControlEvent.getParameters.toId: type: string, description: The ID of the page, which will be displayed after the current navigation.
eventParams.oControlEvent.getParameters.from: type: sap.ui.core.Control, description: The page, which was displayed before the current navigation.
eventParams.oControlEvent.getParameters.isBackToPage: type: boolean, description: Determines whether this was a navigation to a specific page, triggered by backToPage().
eventParams.oControlEvent.getParameters.firstTime: type: boolean, description: Determines whether the "to" page (more precisely: a control with the ID of the page, which is currently being navigated to) has not been displayed/navigated to before.

masterNavigate.name: masterNavigate
masterNavigate.description: Fires when navigation between two pages in master area has been triggered. The transition (if any) to the new page has not started yet. This event can be aborted by the application with preventDefault(), which means that there will be no navigation.

sap.m.semantic.SemanticButton.description: A semantic button is either a {@link sap.m.Button} or {@link sap.m.semantic.SemanticOverflowToolbarButton} , eligible for aggregation content of a {@link sap.m.semantic.SemanticPage}.
sap.m.semantic.SemanticButton.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new SemanticButton. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getEnabled enabled} : boolean (default: true)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:press press} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.m.semantic.SemanticControl#constructor sap.m.semantic.SemanticControl} can be used as well.
sap.m.semantic.SemanticButton.helpDescription: A semantic button is either a {@link sap.m.Button} or {@link sap.m.semantic.SemanticOverflowToolbarButton} , eligible for aggregation content of a {@link sap.m.semantic.SemanticPage}.

sap.m.Bar.description: The Bar control can be used as a header, sub-header and a footer in a page. It has the capability to center a content like a title, while having other controls on the left and right side.
sap.m.Bar.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new Bar. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getEnableFlexBox enableFlexBox} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getTranslucent translucent} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getDesign design} : sap.m.BarDesign (default: Auto)
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getContentLeft contentLeft} : sap.ui.core.Control[]
    • {@link #getContentMiddle contentMiddle} : sap.ui.core.Control[]
    • {@link #getContentRight contentRight} : sap.ui.core.Control[]
  • Associations
    • {@link #getAriaLabelledBy ariaLabelledBy} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Control)[]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.m.Bar.helpDescription: The Bar control can be used as a header, sub-header and a footer in a page. It has the capability to center a content like a title, while having other controls on the left and right side.

layoutData.description: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.
layoutData.helpDescription: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.

contentMiddle.description: Represents the middle content area. Controls such as label, segmented buttons or select can be placed here. The content is centrally positioned if there is enough space. If the right or left content overlaps the middle content, the middle content will be centered in the space between the left and the right content.
contentMiddle.helpDescription: Represents the middle content area. Controls such as label, segmented buttons or select can be placed here. The content is centrally positioned if there is enough space. If the right or left content overlaps the middle content, the middle content will be centered in the space between the left and the right content.

busyIndicatorSize.description: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. If the size could vary in width and the width could get smaller than 3rem, the sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Auto option could be used. The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.

sap.m.NumericContent.description: Shows numeric values used for example in tiles colored according to their meaning and displays deviations.
sap.m.NumericContent.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new sap.m.GenericTile control. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getAnimateTextChange animateTextChange} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getFormatterValue formatterValue} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getIcon icon} : sap.ui.core.URI
    • {@link #getIconDescription iconDescription} : string
    • {@link #getIndicator indicator} : sap.m.DeviationIndicator (default: None)
    • {@link #getNullifyValue nullifyValue} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getScale scale} : string
    • {@link #getSize size} : sap.m.Size (default: Auto)
    • {@link #getTruncateValueTo truncateValueTo} : int (default: 4)
    • {@link #getValue value} : string
    • {@link #getValueColor valueColor} : sap.m.ValueColor (default: Neutral)
    • {@link #getWidth width} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize
    • {@link #getWithMargin withMargin} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getState state} : sap.m.LoadState (default: Loaded)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:press press} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.m.NumericContent.helpDescription: Shows numeric values used for example in tiles colored according to their meaning and displays deviations.

sap.m.ProgressIndicator.description: Shows the progress of a process in a graphical way. To indicate the progress, the inside of the ProgressIndicator is filled with a color. Additionally, a user-defined string can be displayed on the ProgressIndicator.
sap.m.ProgressIndicator.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new ProgressIndicator. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getEnabled enabled} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getState state} : sap.ui.core.ValueState (default: None)
    • {@link #getDisplayValue displayValue} : string
    • {@link #getPercentValue percentValue} : float (default: 0)
    • {@link #getShowValue showValue} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getWidth width} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: 100%)
    • {@link #getHeight height} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize
    • {@link #getTextDirection textDirection} : sap.ui.core.TextDirection (default: Inherit)
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.m.ProgressIndicator.helpDescription: Shows the progress of a process in a graphical way. To indicate the progress, the inside of the ProgressIndicator is filled with a color. Additionally, a user-defined string can be displayed on the ProgressIndicator.

activePage.description: Provides getter and setter for the currently displayed page. For the setter, argument may be the control itself, which must be member of the carousel's page list, or the control's id. The getter will return the control id
activePage.helpDescription: Provides getter and setter for the currently displayed page. For the setter, argument may be the control itself, which must be member of the carousel's page list, or the control's id. The getter will return the control id

sap.m.Carousel.description:
The Carousel control can be used to navigate through a list of sap.m controls just like flipping through the pages of a book by swiping right or left.
An indicator shows the current position within the control list. If the pages are less than 9, the page indicator is represented with bullets. If the pages are 9 or more, the page indicator is numeric.
When displayed in a desktop browser, a left- and right-arrow button is displayed on the carousel's sides, which can be used to navigate through the carousel. Note: When displayed in Internet Explorer 9, page changes are not animated.
sap.m.Carousel.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new Carousel. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getHeight height} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: 100%)
    • {@link #getWidth width} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: 100%)
    • {@link #getLoop loop} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getShowPageIndicator showPageIndicator} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getPageIndicatorPlacement pageIndicatorPlacement} : sap.m.PlacementType (default: Bottom)
    • {@link #getShowBusyIndicator showBusyIndicator} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getArrowsPlacement arrowsPlacement} : sap.m.CarouselArrowsPlacement (default: Content)
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getPages pages} : sap.ui.core.Control[] (default)
  • Associations
    • {@link #getActivePage activePage} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Control)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:loadPage loadPage} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:unloadPage unloadPage} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:pageChanged pageChanged} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.m.Carousel.helpDescription:
The Carousel control can be used to navigate through a list of sap.m controls just like flipping through the pages of a book by swiping right or left.
An indicator shows the current position within the control list. If the pages are less than 9, the page indicator is represented with bullets. If the pages are 9 or more, the page indicator is numeric.
When displayed in a desktop browser, a left- and right-arrow button is displayed on the carousel's sides, which can be used to navigate through the carousel. Note: When displayed in Internet Explorer 9, page changes are not animated.

busyIndicatorSize.description: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. sap.m.Slider.description:
Overview A {@link sap.m.Slider} control represents a numerical range and a handle. The purpose of the control is to enable visual selection of value in a continuous numerical range by moving an adjustable handle. Notes:
  • Only horizontal sliders are possible.
  • The handle can be moved in steps of predefined size. This is done with the step property.
  • Setting the property showAdvancedTooltips shows an input field above the handle
  • Setting the property inputsAsTooltips enables the user to enter a specific value in the handle's tooltip.
Structure The most important properties of the Slider are:
  • min - The minimum value of the slider range
  • max - The maximum value of the slider range
  • value - The current value of the slider
  • progress - Determines if a progress bar will be shown on the slider range
  • step - Determines the increments in which the slider will move
These properties determine the visualization of the tooltips:
  • showAdvancedTooltips - Determines if a tooltip should be displayed above the handle
  • inputsAsTooltips - Determines if the tooltip displayed above the slider's handle should include an input field
Usage The most common usecase is to select values on a continuous numerical scale (e.g. temperature, volume, etc. ). Responsive Behavior The sap.m.Slider control adjusts to the size of its parent container by recalculating and resizing the width of the control. You can move the slider handle in several different ways:
  • Drag and drop to the desired value
  • Click/tap on the range bar to move the handle to that location
  • Enter the desired value in the input field (if available)
  • Keyboard (Arrow keys, "+" and "-")
sap.m.Slider.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new Slider. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getWidth width} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: 100%)
    • {@link #getEnabled enabled} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getName name} : string (default: )
    • {@link #getMin min} : float (default: 0)
    • {@link #getMax max} : float (default: 100)
    • {@link #getStep step} : float (default: 1)
    • {@link #getProgress progress} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getValue value} : float (default: 0)
    • {@link #getShowHandleTooltip showHandleTooltip} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getShowAdvancedTooltip showAdvancedTooltip} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getInputsAsTooltips inputsAsTooltips} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getEnableTickmarks enableTickmarks} : boolean (default: false)
  • Associations
    • {@link #getAriaLabelledBy ariaLabelledBy} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Control)[]
  • Events
    • {@link #event:change change} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:liveChange liveChange} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.

name.description: The name property to be used in the HTML code for the slider (e.g. for HTML forms that send data to the server via submit).

progress.description: Indicate whether a progress bar indicator is shown.

step.description:
Define the amount of units to change the slider when adjusting by drag and drop.

Defines the size of the slider's selection intervals. (e.g. min = 0, max = 10, step = 5 would result in possible selection of the values 0, 5, 10).

The step must be positive, if a negative number is provided, the default value will be used instead. If the width of the slider converted to pixels is less than the range (max – min), the value will be rounded to multiples of the step size.
step.helpDescription:
Define the amount of units to change the slider when adjusting by drag and drop.

Defines the size of the slider's selection intervals. (e.g. min = 0, max = 10, step = 5 would result in possible selection of the values 0, 5, 10).

The step must be positive, if a negative number is provided, the default value will be used instead. If the width of the slider converted to pixels is less than the range (max – min), the value will be rounded to multiples of the step size.

sap.m.TableSelectDialog.description: TableSelectDialog provides you with an easier way to create a dialog that contains a list with grouping and search functionalities. The Table used in a SelectDialog is a Table with Columns. After selecting an item, the dialog is closed and a callback function returns the item being selected.
sap.m.TableSelectDialog.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new TableSelectDialog. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getTitle title} : string
    • {@link #getNoDataText noDataText} : string
    • {@link #getMultiSelect multiSelect} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getGrowingThreshold growingThreshold} : int
    • {@link #getContentWidth contentWidth} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize
    • {@link #getRememberSelections rememberSelections} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getContentHeight contentHeight} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getItems items} : sap.m.ColumnListItem[] (default)
    • {@link #getColumns columns} : sap.m.Column[]
  • Events
    • {@link #event:confirm confirm} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:search search} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:liveChange liveChange} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:cancel cancel} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.m.TableSelectDialog.helpDescription: TableSelectDialog provides you with an easier way to create a dialog that contains a list with grouping and search functionalities. The Table used in a SelectDialog is a Table with Columns. After selecting an item, the dialog is closed and a callback function returns the item being selected.

sap.m.Select.description: The sap.m.Select control provides a list of items that allows users to select an item.
sap.m.Select.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new sap.m.Select. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getName name} : string (default: )
    • {@link #getEnabled enabled} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getWidth width} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: auto)
    • {@link #getMaxWidth maxWidth} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: 100%)
    • {@link #getSelectedKey selectedKey} : string (default: )
    • {@link #getSelectedItemId selectedItemId} : string (default: )
    • {@link #getIcon icon} : sap.ui.core.URI (default: )
    • {@link #getType type} : sap.m.SelectType (default: Default)
    • {@link #getAutoAdjustWidth autoAdjustWidth} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getTextAlign textAlign} : sap.ui.core.TextAlign (default: Initial)
    • {@link #getTextDirection textDirection} : sap.ui.core.TextDirection (default: Inherit)
    • {@link #getValueState valueState} : sap.ui.core.ValueState (default: None)
    • {@link #getValueStateText valueStateText} : string (default: )
    • {@link #getShowSecondaryValues showSecondaryValues} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getForceSelection forceSelection} : boolean (default: true)
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getItems items} : sap.ui.core.Item[] (default)
  • Associations
    • {@link #getSelectedItem selectedItem} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Item)
    • {@link #getAriaLabelledBy ariaLabelledBy} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Control)[]
  • Events
    • {@link #event:change change} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.m.Select.helpDescription: The sap.m.Select control provides a list of items that allows users to select an item.

name.helpDescription: The name to be used in the HTML code (for example, for HTML forms that send data to the server via submit).

width.description: Sets the width of the field. By default, the field width is automatically adjusted to the size of its content and the default width of the field is calculated based on the widest list item in the dropdown list. If the width defined is smaller than its content, only the field width is changed whereas the dropdown list keeps the width of its content. If the dropdown list is wider than the visual viewport, it is truncated and an ellipsis is displayed for each item. For phones, the width of the dropdown list is always the same as the viewport. Note: This property is ignored if the autoAdjustWidth property is set to true.
width.helpDescription: Sets the width of the field. By default, the field width is automatically adjusted to the size of its content and the default width of the field is calculated based on the widest list item in the dropdown list. If the width defined is smaller than its content, only the field width is changed whereas the dropdown list keeps the width of its content. If the dropdown list is wider than the visual viewport, it is truncated and an ellipsis is displayed for each item. For phones, the width of the dropdown list is always the same as the viewport. Note: This property is ignored if the autoAdjustWidth property is set to true.

id.description: Unique ID of this instance. If not given, a so called autoID will be generated by the framework. AutoIDs use a unique prefix that must not be used for Ids that the application (or other code) creates. It can be configured option 'autoIDPrefix', see {@link sap.ui.core.Configuration}.

forceSelection.description: Indicates whether the selection is restricted to one of the items in the list. Note: We strongly recommend that you always set this property to false and bind the selectedKey property to the desired value for better interoperability with data binding.

sap.m.TextArea.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new TextArea. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getRows rows} : int (default: 2)
    • {@link #getCols cols} : int (default: 20)
    • {@link #getHeight height} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize
    • {@link #getMaxLength maxLength} : int (default: 0)
    • {@link #getWrapping wrapping} : sap.ui.core.Wrapping (default: None)
    • {@link #getValueLiveUpdate valueLiveUpdate} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getGrowing growing} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getGrowingMaxLines growingMaxLines} : int (default: 0)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:liveChange liveChange} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.m.InputBase#constructor sap.m.InputBase} can be used as well.
